choices.text: Adenoid cystic carcinoma of the lacrimal gland

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman has suffered visual loss in the right eye for over 3 years. The visual acuity in the left eye is 20/20. Examination of the right eye shows visual acuity of 20/70, a right afferent pupillary defect, 3 mm axial proptosis, and bilaterally normal optic discs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A middle-aged woman with slowly progressive, painless unilateral visual loss over three years, a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), mild axial proptosis, and a normal optic disc on fundoscopic examination suggests Optic Nerve Sheath Meningioma.

  • Optic nerve sheath meningioma is a benign tumor that arises from the meningothelial (arachnoid cap) cells of the optic nerve sheath. It typically affects middle-aged women and is the second most common primary optic nerve tumor after glioma. These tumors are slow-growing and may compress the optic nerve, leading to progressive visual impairment.
  • Clinically, patients usually present with unilateral, painless visual loss, often accompanied by an afferent pupillary defect. Visual acuity decline is gradual. Axial proptosis may occur due to the mass effect within the orbit, and optic disc appearance may initially be normal-especially if the tumor is retrobulbar-but may later show optic atrophy or optociliary shunt vessels.
  • Imaging (MRI with contrast) is key for diagnosis, typically revealing a "tram-track" sign representing enhancement of the meningioma along the optic nerve sheath.
  • Treatment is usually observation in stable cases, but radiotherapy is the mainstay if vision worsens. Surgical excision is avoided unless vision is already lost, due to the high risk of optic nerve damage.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Adenoid cystic carcinoma of the lacrimal gland (Option A):

This tumor typically presents with painful, rapidly progressive proptosis due to perineural invasion. It often causes superotemporal orbital fullness and is associated with bony destruction on imaging. The absence of pain and the chronic, indolent nature of symptoms in this patient make this diagnosis unlikely.

Orbital lymphoma (Option B):

Orbital lymphoma usually presents in older adults and typically causes painless proptosis or orbital swelling, often without early vision loss. When it affects vision, it is due to mass effect, but optic nerve dysfunction(RAPD) is less common in the early stages. Imaging shows a well-defined homogenous mass, often molding to adjacent structures, rather than a lesion centered around the optic nerve.

Optic nerve glioma (Option C):

Optic nerve glioma is more commonly seen in children, particularly in association with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). It typically presents before the age of 10. In adults, optic gliomas are rare and tend to be more aggressive. Also, gliomas tend to cause more pronounced optic disc changes (e.g., swelling or atrophy) and often show fusiform enlargement of the optic nerve on imaging, which may not align with the subtle signs in this case.

choices.text: Fusiform enlargement of the optic nerve

questions.text: Optic nerve gliomas demonstrate what finding on computer axial tomography(CT) imaging?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Optic nerve gliomas, typically seen in children and often associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), are benign astrocytic tumors involving the optic nerve. On computed axial tomography (CT) imaging, the hallmark finding is fusiform (spindle-shaped) enlargement of the optic nerve. This appearance reflects the intrinsic growth of the tumor within the nerve, causing it to expand in a smooth, uniform fashion along its length.

They can involve the intraorbital, intracanalicular, or intracranial segments of the optic nerve. Clinically, patients may present with slowly progressive unilateral visual loss, proptosis, strabismus, or optic disc pallor/swelling. In patients with NF1, these tumors are often bilateral and may remain asymptomatic or non-progressive.

CT Imaging Features:

  • Fusiform enlargement of the optic nerve is the classic finding.
  • The lesion may show mild to moderate enhancement with contrast.
  • Calcification is rare, unlike optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Bony remodeling of the optic canal may be seen in chronic cases.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Hyperostosis of the sphenoid bone (Option B): Seen in optic nerve sheath meningioma, not glioma.

Erosion of the lamina papyracea (Option C): Seen in aggressive orbital masses or sinonasal tumors, not typical of gliomas.

Attenuated optic nerve (Option D): Seen in optic nerve atrophy, such as after ischemic or traumatic injury-not in gliomas, which cause enlargement, not thinning.

questions.text: What is the mainstay of treatment for rhabdomyosarcoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in children, arising from skeletal muscle progenitor cells. It is an aggressive malignancy that requires multimodal therapy. The mainstay of treatment is a combination of chemotherapy and radiation therapy, which is critical for both local and systemic disease control.

  • Chemotherapy is essential because RMS has a high potential for micrometastasis, even when it appears localized. The standard chemotherapeutic regimen includes vincristine, actinomycin D, and cyclophosphamide (VAC regimen).
  • Radiation therapy is used to achieve local control, especially in cases where complete surgical excision is not feasible or might cause significant morbidity.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Immunotherapy (Option B):

Immunotherapy is not a standard treatment for rhabdomyosarcoma. It remains under investigation in clinical trials but is not part of first-line therapy.

Surgery (Option C):

While surgery is performed when feasible, it is not the mainstay due to the tumor's location and risk of functional or cosmetic impairment. Many cases are not amenable to complete resection.

Observation (Option D):

Observation is not appropriate for rhabdomyosarcoma due to its aggressive nature and high metastatic potential. Delaying treatment can worsen the prognosis.

questions.text: Systemic association with limbal dermoid involves all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Limbal dermoids are benign congenital choristomas typically located at the inferotemporal limbus. They often present in infancy or early childhood and may be isolated or associated with systemic syndromes.

UGH (Uveitis-Glaucoma-Hyphema) syndrome is a mechanical complication caused by malpositioned or rubbing intraocular lenses (IOLs), typically following cataract surgery. It is not a congenital disorder and has no association with limbal dermoids.

Systemic associations of limbal dermoids:

  • Goldenhar syndrome (Option A):

Also known as oculo-auriculo-vertebral dysplasia, it commonly presents with limbal dermoids, preauricular skin tags, and vertebral anomalies. Limbal dermoid is a classic ocular feature of this syndrome.

  • Treacher Collins Syndrome (Option B):

A disorder affecting craniofacial development. While less commonly than in Goldenhar, ocular dermoidsincluding limbal dermoids can be present, often as part of broader craniofacial anomalies.

  • Linear naevus sebaceous of Jadassohn (Option D):

A neurocutaneous syndrome involving sebaceous nevi, neurologic defects, and ocular abnormalities, including limbal dermoids, coloboma, and epibulbar lesions.

questions.text: A 10-month old, full-term gestation and previously healthy child, presents for further evaluation of leukocoria(white pupil) in his left eye, which was first noted by the child's parents in a recent photograph. A CT scan shows evidence of a mass with localized calcification in the left eye. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In this case, a healthy 10-month-old full-term infant presents with leukocoria in the left eye, and a CT scan reveals an intraocular mass with localized calcification-a hallmark radiologic feature of Retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the developing retinal cells and usually presents in children under the age of 3. It can occur in a sporadic (unilateral) form or a heritable (often bilateral) form due to a mutation in the RB1 tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 13q14. The most common presenting sign is leukocoria (white pupil), followed by strabismus, decreased vision, or, in advanced cases, a painful red eye due to secondary glaucoma. The leukocoria results from the tumor reflecting light through the pupil, particularly visible in flash photographs.

CT scan may reveal calcifications within the mass, which are highly suggestive of retinoblastoma. MRI is preferred for evaluating extraocular extension and optic nerve involvement, as it does not expose the child to ionizing radiation and provides better soft tissue detail. Ocular ultrasound can also detect a solid intraocular mass with calcification.

Treatment depends on the extent of the disease (intraocular vs. extraocular, unilateral vs. bilateral) . Management may include systemic chemotherapy (chemoreduction), and enucleation (surgical removal of the eye) for large or visionless eyes with extensive disease. Radiation therapy is less commonly used now due to the risk of secondary malignancies, especially in heritable cases. Genetic counseling and long-term follow-up are essential in bilateral or familial cases.

Organized vitreous hemorrhage (Option A):

This can occasionally present with leukocoria if the hemorrhage becomes dense or fibrotic. However, it does not produce an intraocular mass and does not show calcification on imaging. It typically occurs secondary to trauma, retinopathy of prematurity, or systemic vascular disorders-all of which are not present in this previously healthy, full-term infant.

Retinopathy of prematurity (Option B):

ROP affects preterm, low-birth-weight infants, especially those with prolonged oxygen exposure. This child is full-term, which rules out ROP clinically. Furthermore, ROP may lead to retinal detachment and leukocoria, but it does not cause calcification or a discrete intraocular mass on CT scan, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

Coats disease (Option C):

Typically presents in older male children (usually age 5-10 years) with unilateral vision loss or leukocoria due to exudative retinal detachment. Although it can mimic retinoblastoma clinically, Coats disease does not show calcification on imaging and presents with subretinal exudates rather than a solid intraocular tumor. The age and radiologic findings in this case are not consistent with Coats disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has bilateral optic atrophy, bilateral deafness, cataracts, and premacular membranes. Assuming that all of these findings are due to a single condition, for what condition should she be evaluated?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 30-year-old woman presents with a constellation of bilateral optic atrophy, bilateral deafness, cataracts, and premacular membranes-a pattern highly suggestive of Neurofibromatosis type II,

NF2 is caused by mutations in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22, which encodes merlin, a tumor suppressor protein. Unlike NF1, which presents with skin findings like cafe-au-lait spots and neurofibromas, NF2 is more commonly associated with cranial and spinal tumors (especially schwannomas, meningiomas, and ependymomas) and ocular manifestations.

Key clinical features:

  • Bilateral vestibular schwannomas: hallmark, leading to hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance issues
  • Optic nerve meningiomas or gliomas: causing optic atrophy
  • Cataracts: particularly early-onset, posterior subcapsular or cortical
  • Retinal abnormalities: including epiretinal membranes, combined hamartomas

Investigations:

  • MRI brain with contrast: to evaluate for bilateral vestibular schwannomas and other intracranial lesions
  • Audiometry: for hearing loss
  • Ophthalmic exam and OCT: to assess cataracts, optic nerve, and premacular membranes
  • Genetic testing: to confirm NF2 mutations

Explanation of incorrect options:

Pseudotumor cerebri (Option A):

Typically causes papilledema due to increased intracranial pressure, not optic atrophy unless chronic and untreated. It does not cause deafness, cataracts, or premacular membranes, making it an unlikely unifying diagnosis.

Multiple sclerosis (Option C):

It can cause optic neuritis and optic atrophy, but does not cause bilateral deafness, cataracts, or premacular membranes. MS is primarily a demyelinating CNS disorder with neurological deficits like limb weakness, sensory changes, and internuclear ophthalmoplegia.

Joubert's syndrome (Option D):

A rare congenital disorder associated with cerebellar malformations, hypotonia, developmental delay, and ocular motor apraxia, often diagnosed in infancy or early childhood. It does not explain deafness and cataracts in a 30-year-old adult.

choices.text: Central scotomas on visual field testing

questions.text: A woman had idiopathic intracranial hypertension(pseudotumor cerebri). What would be the most common early finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common and earliest ophthalmologic finding in Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension (IIH)-also known as pseudotumor cerebri-is bilateral optic disc edema, also called papilledema. This condition results from elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) without any detectable intracranial mass, hydrocephalus, or infection, and it most commonly affects young, obese women of childbearing age.

Increased intracranial pressure is transmitted via the subarachnoid space surrounding the optic nerve, causing axoplasmic flow stasis and swelling of the optic disc. This swelling is almost always bilateral and often symmetric, though early in the disease, it can be subtle.

Clinical features:

  • Headache (most common symptom)
  • Transient visual obscurations
  • Pulsatile tinnitus
  • Diplopia (often due to sixth nerve palsy)
  • Visual field defects, typically enlarged blind spot and inferonasal defects, progressing to peripheral field loss if untreated

Investigations:

  • Fundoscopy: Shows bilateral papilledema
  • MRI brain with MRV: Usually normal, but done to rule out mass lesions or venous sinus thrombosis
  • Lumbar puncture: Shows elevated opening pressure, with normal CSF composition

Explanation of incorrect options:

Central scotomas on visual field testing (Option A):

Central scotomas are more characteristic of optic neuritis, such as in multiple sclerosis. In IIH, the early visual field defect is an enlarged blind spot or peripheral constriction, not central vision loss.

Elevated protein on CSF analysis (Option B):

In IIH, CSF composition is normal. The hallmark finding is elevated opening pressure, but protein levels are not elevated.

Ventriculomegaly on MRI of the brain (Option C):

IIH is defined by normal ventricular size. Ventricles may appear slit-like.

Ventriculomegaly suggests hydrocephalus, not IIH.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is referred to you by her neurosurgeon after removal of a cerebellar hemangioma. Which of the following are you most likely to find?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A 30-year-old woman with a history of cerebellar hemangioma raises strong suspicion for Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease, a rare autosomal dominant condition associated with the formation of multiple tumors and cysts in various organs. One of the classic ocular findings in VHL is a retinal capillary hemangioma, also known as a retinal hemangioblastoma.

Retinal capillary hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors of the retina strongly associated with VHL disease.

They may be asymptomatic or cause visual loss due to exudation, retinal detachment, or vitreous hemorrhage.

These lesions are often multiple and bilateral in VHL.

Fundoscopy shows a red, round lesion with dilated feeding and draining vessels, commonly found in the peripheral retina or near the optic disc.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is referred to your office for evaluation of left lower eyelid ecchymosis. There is 3 mm of proptosis of the left eye. Her medical history is significant for the treatment of an unknown tumor. Which of the following childhood tumors is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a 2-year-old child presenting with periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes) and proptosis, especially with a history of a previously treated tumor, the most likely diagnosis is neuroblastoma with orbital metastasis. This classic clinical picture-unilateral or bilateral periorbital bruising and proptosis-is a hallmark of metastatic neuroblastoma, which commonly spreads to the orbit and bones.

  • Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor of childhood, typically arising from the adrenal medullaor sympathetic ganglia.
  • It often presents before the age of 5, and metastatic disease is common at diagnosis, especially to bone, bone marrow, liver, and orbit.
  • Periorbital ecchymosis occurs due to orbital bone metastasis, leading to bleeding and infiltration of periorbital tissues.
  • Proptosis results from mass effect in the orbit.
  • Other signs may include abdominal mass, weight loss, irritability, and bone pain.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option A):

This is the most common primary orbital malignancy in children and can present with rapid-onset proptosis. However, it typically does not cause ecchymosis unless there's hemorrhage or trauma. It originates within the orbit, not as a systemic metastasis.

Retinoblastoma (Option B):

Usually presents with leukocoria and sometimes strabismus. Proptosis and ecchymosis are late findings in advanced, extraocular disease, and even then, not typical. It does not commonly metastasize to the orbit like neuroblastoma.

Leukemia (Option D):

Can infiltrate the orbit or cause subconjunctival hemorrhages, but periorbital ecchymosis and proptosis are not classic early signs. More commonly presents with pallor, bruising, fever, and organomegaly.

choices.text: Progressive visual loss, optic atrophy and opticociliary shunt vessels
Sudden Visual Loss, Optic atrophy and opticociliary shunt vessels
Progressive visual loss, optic nerve edema and opticociliary shunt vessels
Sudden Visual Loss, Optic nerve edema and opticociliary shunt vessels

questions.text: Hoyt-Spencer Triad consists of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Hoyt-Spencer triad is a classic clinical finding seen in optic nerve sheath meningioma. It comprises:

  1. Progressive visual loss - due to chronic compression of the optic nerve by the tumor.
  2. Optic atrophy - resulting from long-standing damage to the optic nerve fibers.
  3. Opticociliary shunt vessels - these are collateral channels between the retinal and choroidal circulations, formed due to chronic venous obstruction. They appear as dilated, tortuous vessels on the optic disc.

This triad is highly suggestive of a compressive optic neuropathy, particularly optic nerve sheath meningioma, which tends to cause slow, painless vision loss in middle-aged women.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Sudden Visual Loss (Options B and D):

Sudden vision loss is not typical of optic nerve sheath meningioma. The vision loss is gradual and progressive, which helps differentiate it from vascular or inflammatory causes.

Optic nerve edema (Options C and D):

While optic disc swelling can occur in the early stages of optic nerve sheath meningioma, the triad specifically refers to optic atrophy, a later and more characteristic finding. Therefore, the inclusion of edema instead of atrophy makes these options incorrect.

questions.text: Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, Homer Wright rosettes and fleurettes are seen in
questions.solution:
Retinoblastoma, the most common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood, is characterized histopathologically by the presence of distinctive rosettes and other cellular arrangements. The three key microscopic features seen in retinoblastoma include:

  1. Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes - These are true rosettes, consisting of tumor cells arranged in a circular fashion around an empty central lumen. They are specific to retinoblastoma and indicate photoreceptor differentiation.
  2. Homer Wright rosettes - These are pseudo-rosettes where tumor cells are arranged in a radial fashion around a central area filled with neuropil, not an empty lumen. Though seen in neuroblastoma and medulloblastoma, they may also appear in retinoblastoma due to its neuroectodermal origin.
  3. Fleurettes - These are clusters of well-differentiated tumor cells with eosinophilic cytoplasmic processes, resembling mature photoreceptors. They are seen in well-differentiated retinoblastoma and suggest benign behavior.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option B):

A soft tissue tumor of mesenchymal origin that shows strap cells and cross striations, not rosettes or fleurettes.

Optic Nerve Glioma (Option C):

A low-grade astrocytic tumor typically seen in children, especially those with NF1. It lacks rosettes or fleurettes and shows pilocytic astrocytoma features, such as Rosenthal fibers.

Sebaceous Gland Carcinoma (Option D):

An aggressive eyelid tumor showing pagetoid spread, foamy cytoplasm, and lobular architecture, but no rosette formation.

questions.text: Trilateral Retinoblastoma is a bilateral retinoblastoma with
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Trilateral retinoblastoma refers to the occurrence of bilateral retinoblastoma (tumors in both eyes) along with an intracranial midline neuroblastic tumor, most commonly a pinealoblastoma. It is seen in patients with the heritable form of retinoblastoma due to germline mutations in the RB1 gene.

The intracranial tumor arises in the pineal gland, which-like the retina-is derived from neuroectodermal tissue. In some cases, a similar tumor can also arise in the suprasellar region, but the classic location is the pineal gland.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Osteosarcoma (Option A):

While osteosarcoma is a known second primary tumor in survivors of heritable retinoblastoma (especially those treated with radiation), it does not define trilateral retinoblastoma.

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option B):

Another potential second malignancy in retinoblastoma survivors, but not part of the trilateral presentation.

Soft Tissue Sarcoma (Option D):

Also associated with increased risk in patients with germline RB1 mutations, particularly after radiation therapy, but again, not part of the trilateral definition.

questions.text: Which chemotherapeutic drugs are given for the treatment of Retinoblastoma ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The standard chemotherapy regimen used in the treatment of retinoblastoma is known as the VEC regimen, which includes:

  • Vincristine - a mitotic inhibitor that interferes with microtubule formation.
  • Etoposide - a topoisomerase II inhibitor that prevents DNA unwinding.
  • Carboplatin - a platinum-based alkylating agent that damages DNA and inhibits replication.

This combination therapy is used for chemoreduction, especially in intraocular retinoblastoma, to shrink the tumor and facilitate the use of focal treatments (e.g., laser photocoagulation, cryotherapy, thermotherapy) or to delay or avoid enucleation. It can be given systemically or via intra-arterial or intravitreal routes, depending on tumor size, location, and laterality.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Vincristine, Etoposide, Cyclophosphamide (Option B):
This regimen is used in other pediatric tumors (e.g., rhabdomyosarcoma, neuroblastoma), but cyclophosphamide is not a part of standard retinoblastoma treatment.

Etoposide and Carboplatin (Option C):
While both are effective agents, the absence of vincristine makes this an incomplete regimen for standard therapy.

Vincristine alone (Option D):
Monotherapy is inadequate for retinoblastoma. Combination therapy is necessary for effective tumor control and chemoreduction.

questions.text: Leucocoria can be seen in all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Leucocoria means "white pupil" (from Greek leukos = white, kore = pupil). Clinically, it refers to an abnormal white reflex seen in the pupil when light is shone into the eye.

Conditions associated with Leucocoria:

choices.text: Large tumour filling the vitreous cavity

questions.text: All are indications of enucleation in retinoblastoma except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Enucleation, or surgical removal of the eyeball, is a treatment option in retinoblastoma when the eye is unsalvageable, vision is lost, and there is a risk of tumor spread.

It is typically reserved for advanced intraocular disease. Indications for enucleation include:

  • A large tumor filling the vitreous cavity, as such a mass generally occupies the entire eye, rendering vision restoration impossible and posing a high risk of extraocular extension. (Option A)
  • A painful blind eye is another classic indication, especially when secondary complications like glaucoma or tumor necrosis cause significant discomfort. (Option B)
  • Similarly, neovascular glaucoma, which results from tumor-induced ischemia and leads to elevated intraocular pressure and pain, is also a common indication for enucleation. (Option C)

Vitreous invasion, or vitreous seeding, refers to free-floating tumor cells within the vitreous cavity. Although it reflects intraocular tumor dissemination, it is not an absolute indication for enucleation. With advances in chemotherapy-especially intravitreal injections-these seeds can often be controlled without removing the eye. Therefore, vitreous invasion alone does not necessitate enucleation.

questions.text: What is the most common diagnosis of this picture at birth
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a case of congenital cataract, which is the most common cause of leucocoria at birth. Congenital cataract refers to an opacity of the lens present at or shortly after birth, which obstructs the red reflex and appears as a white pupillary reflex. It may be unilateral or bilateral and can lead to permanent visual impairment or amblyopia if not treated early. Early identification and prompt surgical intervention are crucial, especially in bilateral cases, to ensure proper visual development.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Retinoblastoma (Option A):

Although retinoblastoma is a common cause of leucocoria in children, it typically presents between 6 months and 3 years of age. It is rarely present at birth and is therefore unlikely to be the diagnosis in a newborn with leucocoria.

Toxocariasis (Option C):

Ocular toxocariasis is caused by larval infection from Toxocara canis and usually presents in older children, not in neonates. It is an acquired parasitic infection and is not present at birth.

Persistent Hyperplastic Primary Vitreous (PHPV) (Option D):

PHPV is a congenital malformation of the eye and can present with leucocoria at birth. It is usually unilateral, associated with a small eye (microphthalmia), and sometimes with cataract. However, it is less common than congenital cataract and therefore not the most likely diagnosis in this context.

questions.text: The most common tumour associated with patients of retinoblastoma is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Patients with heritable (germline) retinoblastoma-who typically present with bilateral or multifocal tumors-are at increased risk for developing second primary tumors, especially due to mutations in the RB1 tumor suppressor gene.

One of the most well-known associated tumors is pinealoblastoma, a primitive neuroectodermal tumor arising in the pineal gland. When a patient with bilateral retinoblastoma develops a pinealoblastoma, the condition is referred to as trilateral retinoblastoma.

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Neuroblastoma (Option A):

While neuroblastoma is a common childhood tumor, it is not specifically associated with retinoblastoma.

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option C):

This is a soft tissue tumor of muscle origin, seen in children but not commonly linked with retinoblastoma patients.

Osteosarcoma (Option D):

Osteosarcoma is a common second primary malignancy in retinoblastoma survivors, especially those treated with radiation. However, it tends to occur later in life, not as an associated tumor in early childhood like pinealoblastoma.

questions.text: A 7-year-old baby was taken by the mother to the OPD with complaints of leucocoria for a few months. The retina showed this picture. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Coats' disease is an idiopathic, non-hereditary retinal disorder characterized by retinal telangiectasia, aneurysmal dilatation of vessels, and massive subretinal exudation, often leading to exudative retinal detachment. It most commonly affects young boys, typically presenting between 6-8 years of age with unilateral painless visual loss or leucocoria.

The retinal image in such cases usually shows:

  • Yellowish subretinal exudates (rich in cholesterol)
  • Telangiectatic vessels
  • Retinal detachment (in later stages)

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Retinoblastoma (Option A):

Though it is the most common cause of leucocoria in infants, it usually presents before 3 years of age. In a 7-year-old, retinoblastoma is less likely, and imaging (e.g., ultrasound or CT) typically shows intraocular calcification, which is absent in Coats' disease.

PHPV - Persistent Hyperplastic Primary Vitreous (Option C):

PHPV is a congenital condition, usually presenting at birth or within the first few months of life. It is typically unilateral, associated with microphthalmia, cataract, and a retrolental fibrovascular mass.

Endophthalmitis (Option D):

Endophthalmitis is a severe intraocular infection, usually presenting with pain, redness, photophobia, and visual loss. It is not a typical cause of leucocoria and does not cause a chronic, painless course with retinal telangiectasia and exudation.

questions.text: Vortex vein invasion is seen in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vortex vein invasion is seen in malignant melanoma of the eye, particularly choroidal melanoma.

Malignant melanoma of the uveal tract (especially choroidal melanoma) is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults. These tumors are highly vascular and can invade through the sclera and enter the vortex veins, which are responsible for draining the choroidal circulation. Vortex vein invasion is a key histopathological feature and an important pathway for hematogenous spread, especially to the liver, which is the most common site of metastasis.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Retinoblastoma (Option A):

Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular malignancy in children, and while it shows local invasion (optic nerve, choroid, sclera), vortex vein invasion is not typical. It spreads via the optic nerve or subarachnoid space and can also seed into the vitreous or anterior chamber.

Optic nerve glioma (Option B):

Optic nerve glioma is a benign tumor often associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). It arises from the optic nerve and does not involve the uveal tract or choroidal vessels, hence does not invade vortex veins.

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option D):

Orbital rhabdomyosarcoma is a soft tissue tumor commonly affecting children, typically involving the orbit, not the intraocular structures like choroid or retina. It spreads locally and via lymphatics but does not involve vortex veins.

questions.text: Most common distant site of metastasis in malignant melanoma
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common distant site of metastasis in malignant melanoma of the eye, particularly uveal (choroidal) melanoma, is the liver.

Uveal melanoma, the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults, spreads hematogenously rather than through lymphatics, since the uvea lacks lymphatic vessels. Among distant organs, the liver is the most commonly involved, with up to 90% of metastatic cases showing liver involvement. This strong hepatic tropism is a distinctive feature of uveal melanoma, unlike cutaneous melanoma, which may spread widely to lymph nodes, lungs, brain, and other organs.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Brain (Option A):

While brain metastases are common in cutaneous melanoma, they are relatively less frequent in uveal melanoma, especially as the initial site of metastasis.

Lung (Option B):

Lung metastasis may occur in systemic spread, but not as commonly as the liver in uveal melanoma.

Lymph node (Option D):

Uveal melanoma does not spread via lymphatics due to the absence of lymphatic channels in the eye. Therefore, lymph node involvement is rare.
